channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Chinese Premier Urges Officials to Fight Events That Led 4 Children to Drink Pesticide
item.description: The impoverished youths, three sisters and a brother ages 5 to 13, were some of the country’s “left-behind children,” and the police had explored the possibility that their deaths were suicides.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Corruption Scandals Drive Protests in Guatemala and Honduras
item.description: Middle-class citizens in both countries are fed up with bribery and other government scandals and increasingly demanding the resignation of their presidents.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Protesters in Guatemala City last month demanding the resignation of President Otto Pérez Molina.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Zhang Weiwei on Why China Will Succeed Under the Communist Party
item.description: Mr. Zhang, a leading theorist of the “China model” of political and economic development, holds that China is on the right path and is destined to accomplish its goals.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Zhang Weiwei directs the Center for China Development Model Research at Fudan University.

item.title: Germany Drops Inquiry Into Claims U.S. Tapped Angela Merkel’s Phone
item.description: The investigation over allegations of eavesdropping by the N.S.A. was ended because of a lack of concrete evidence, a federal prosecutor said.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany in 2013.

item.title: Dominique Strauss-Kahn Acquitted of Pimping Charges
item.description: The verdict closed a four-year legal battle that captivated France and shined an uncomfortable spotlight on the sexual activities of rich and powerful men.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, in Paris on Friday.

item.title: 4 Tourists Accused of Stripping Naked Atop Malaysian Peak Plead Guilty
item.description: The Westerners, whose actions were blamed for causing an earthquake, were fined about $1,300 apiece, and were set to be deported.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Lindsey Peterson of Canada, center right, and Dylan Snel of the Netherlands, center left, arriving at a courthouse in Kota Kinabalu, Malaysia, on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Soccer Fans Boo Chinese National Anthem
item.description: Hong Kong has chafed at times over its return to partial Chinese control in 1997. The tensions have been exacerbated by tens of millions of mainland Chinese who visit Hong Kong every year, driving up the cost of consumer goods and real estate.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Hong Kong fans celebrated after their team scored a goal during the 2018 World Cup Asian qualifying match against Bhutan.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Soil Contamination Found Near Huge Mine in Western China
item.description: Greenpeace East Asia said that soil near a zinc and lead mine and smelting plant in Yunnan Province was unsafe for growing food.
item.dc:creator: CHERIE CHAN
item.media:description: An aerial view of Asia’s largest zinc and lead mine, in Jinding, Yunnan Province.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Unshaven and Proud: Winners of the Chinese Women’s Armpit Contest
item.description: A women’s rights advocate who organized the contest said she received 46 photos of unshaven armpits during the two-week contest.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO and DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: C.E.O. of Orange Meets With Netanyahu to Apologize for Remarks
item.description: Stéphane Richard, the executive, said his comments were “distorted and misunderstood” as part of a boycott movement targeting companies that operate in Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Gil Cohen Magen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An Israeli flag covering the logo of the French telecommunications company Orange in Rosh Haayin, Israel, on Thursday.

item.title: Myanmar to Bar Rohingya From Fleeing, but Won’t Address Their Plight
item.description: The government says it will stop the minority from leaving on traffickers’ boats, but it refuses to address the circumstances that drive so many to seek escape.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rashid Ahmad, a 13-year-old who has no control over his arms and legs, was comforted by his mother at “plastic camp,” part of a government camp in Sittwe, Myanmar, named for the scavenged materials residents have used to improvise dwellings. Doctors said he had polio, his mother says.

item.title: Myanmar’s Missing Rohingya
item.description: Some 140,000 Rohingya Muslims, a persecuted ethnic group in Myanmar, are confined to a squalid government encampment in Sittwe. Tens of thousands have fled, setting out on a risky sea voyage. Many are still missing.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: An area called "plastic camp," named for the scavenged materials the Rohingya have used to improvise dwellings, in Sittwe, Myanmar.

item.title: Rupert Murdoch to Put Media Empire in Sons’ Hands
item.description: Mr. Murdoch put the succession plan in place in March 2014 when he named his sons James and Lachlan to senior positions in his companies.
item.dc:creator: EMILY STEEL and RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: The succession plans for Rupert Murdoch’s media empire have long been the subject of fevered speculation.

item.title: Indian Journalist Who Linked Official to Graft Dies
item.description: Before he died of burns, the journalist, Jagendra Singh, said police officers and associates of a local official had set him afire. The police said they were investigating.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: David Guttenfelder, a Photojournalist, Answers Readers’ Questions on North Korea
item.description: Mr. Guttenfelder has been to North Korea about 40 times. He answers questions on working conditions, local cuisine and American TV.
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The square in front of Pyongyang Railway Station.

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: Blogger’s Allies Rebuffed
item.description: Saudi Arabia rejected foreign criticism of the flogging punishment of Raif Badawi, a blogger who has come to symbolize the kingdom’s oppressive restraints on free speech.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: China: Fatal Shooting at Korean Border
item.description: The person was shot after resisting arrest, the government of Helong, a city in China’s northeast, said on its microblog.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Save the Children Group Is Shut Down in Pakistan
item.description: The Pakistani authorities on Thursday shut down the aid group’s office in Islamabad and ordered its foreign staff members to leave the country within 15 days.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Obama Looks at Adding Bases and Troops in Iraq, to Fight ISIS
item.description: The move would require at least hundreds more American military trainers to help Iraqi forces retake cities lost to the Sunni militants.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER, HELENE COOPER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, at a graduation and commissioning ceremony at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., last month.

item.title: A Chinese Ebola Drug Raises Hopes, and Rancor
item.description: The production of an experimental Ebola treatment by a small Chinese company has led to patent infringement claims by American officials and disagreements among doctors.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: The lab at Beijing Mabworks, which developed the experimental drug, MIL77, used to treat Ebola.
